The Kings of Jazz - Compiled by Gilles Peterson and Jazzanova

From classic true jazz to jazz-infuenced futurisms, this two disc set brings us "The History" and "The Present" of jazz. Helping to filter out some worthy tracks from jazz's extensive history is Gilles Peterson, whose selections on "The History" disc include Rashaan Roland Kirk's "Spirits Up Above," a kind of funky sung jazz band number that halfway makes me think of the "Hair" musical; lonely, rainy night brass jazz with delicious vocals both male and female on Charles Mingus' "Moves"; the jazz classicism of Mark Murphy's "My Favorite Things," putting to shame Julie Andrew's version; the hip smoothness of John coltrane on "Equinox." Others on disc one include Roy Haynes, Randy Weston, Art Blakely, The Jazz Crusaders, Eric Dolphy and Bill Evans. The second disc explores more modernistic modes, touching on music that may not seem like jazz - in some cases - but is definitely endowed with roots in jazz. Examine the sexy soul jazz-it-up of Nikki O's "Butterflies" or the funktified kickalong of "Mother of the Future" by Bembe Segue. You can immerse yourself in the dark, almost foreboding sound of Two Banks of Four performing "Two Miles Before Dawn." You can even enter electronic chillout territory with "At Les" by the Innerzone Orchestra. Others on this disc are 4 Hero, The Matthew Herbert Big Band feat. Jamie Lidell, Pavel Kostiuk feat. Vanessa Freeman, Rima feat. Ian O'Brien, Carlo Fashion and Hedvig Hanson. These "Present" selections were made by the Jazzanova collective. All told this is a wonderful exploration of jazz and jazz offshoots, boasting an eclectic (for sure) batch of tracks, a selection of smart, alluring music to drift through for a while.

Tracklist:

The History
1-01 Roy Haynes Quiet Fire
1-02 Randy Watson In Memory Of
1-03 Rahsaan Roland Kirk & The Vibration Society Spirits Up Above
1-04 Charles Mingus Moves
1-05 Art Blakey Anthenagin
1-06 Jazz Crusaders, The* Young Rabbits
1-07 Mark Murphy My Favourite Things

1-09 Eric Dolphy Fire Waltz

Collage name # torrents
Rapster Records 31
Compilation info
Highly recommended pair of unmixed compilations from undisputed tastemakers Gilles Peterson ("classic" jazz on Disc 1) and Jazzanova ("nujazz" on Disc 2) that showcase the roots of jazz influence on modern electronic and dance music (Art Blakey's "Anthenagin", track 1-10, is as astonishing as it is obscure). None of the selections are obvious (the tendency for tastemaking labels like BBE is consciously to dig deeper into record crates) but, individually and collectively, the tracks comprise an eminently accessible collection of rare gems that are nevertheless delightfully representative of their respective genres. What is astonishing is how similar the two discs sound: perhaps not a coincidence, but some variety would have elevated the listening experience. My other criticism is that Peterson's selections ignore everything before the cool jazz movement of the 1950's. While it may be harder to play "connect the dots to modern music" with Louis Armstrong, Teddy Wilson, and Charlie Parker, these artists, together with Miles Davis, are clearly members of the jazz royalty whose influence on the electronica/dance ecosystem cannot be discounted. And those who are familiar with Wagram's Saint-Germain-Des–Prés Café series of "electro-jazz" compilations will no doubt get a sense of déja vu on Disc 2, but this one is arguably more "exclusive".
